title-group.article-title: A re-examination of the empirical performance of the Longstaff and Schwartz two-factor term structure model using real yield data

contrib.aff: Finance Cluster, UQ Business School, Australia
Accounting and Finance, UWA Business School, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Sirimon Treepongkaruna, Accounting and Finance, UWA Business School, 35 Stirling Highway, Crawley, WA, Australia. Email: sirimon.treepongkaruna@uwa.edu.au

permissions.copyright-holder: The University of New South Wales

abstract.p: In this study, we apply the Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) two-factor term structure model to real yields across eight countries. As such, we improve on many prior studies that have inappropriately tested this formulation using nominal yield data. We use the generalized method of moments to test the cross-sectional restrictions imposed by the Longstaff and Schwartz model, as well as the Cox–Ingersoll–Ross one-factor model. Further, we compare the forecasting ability from both models. Our findings support the superiority of the two-factor model. We confirm general reliability of prior research in this area, despite the unfortunate reliance on nominal data in such earlier tests.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Short-term interest rates play a range of important roles in modern economies. Traditionally, the short rate is a key instrument for policy makers to manipulate monetary policy to influence the macro-economy. It is also a key input for the valuation process of all fixed-income securities and derivatives, the implementation of optimal hedging strategies, dynamic hedging and trading of bonds and portfolio allocation decisions. As a result, modelling short-term interest rates has been one of the most studied topics in modern finance.

One area of keen interest has been the formal modelling of the term structure. Logically these models began with the simplest case based on a single-factor setup. However, in the 1980s, researchers demonstrated the inadequacy of such formulations and developed multiple-factor approaches (see, for example, Stambaugh, 1988; Brennan and Schwartz, 1982). Most notably, for the current paper, Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) pointed out that one of the inadequacies of the single-factor short-rate model is that it implies that the instantaneous real returns on bonds of all maturities are perfectly correlated. Hence, they extend the Cox, Ingersoll and Ross (CIR) (1985) one-factor specification to a two-factor model of the term structure of interest rates. The Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) model (‘LS2 model’) is theoretically appealing. It is developed to value interest-rate-sensitive contingent claims in the real economy. It belongs to the general equilibrium approach of term structure modelling. Hence, using the Longstaff and Schwartz approach it is possible to endogenously determine the term structure, its dynamics and the functional form of the market price of risk.

One objection against many multifactor models of the term structure is that the valuation problem is made complicated and in many cases intractable. This, however, is not the case with the LS2 model. LS2 provides closed-form formulae for bond pricing and its derivatives. Although the LS2 model is theoretically sound, their empirical work tests the term structure model of real rates using nominal rate data. Bakshi and Chen (1996) show that the nominal and real term structures can have completely different properties, including fundamentally different risk structures. Thus, an open question is how well the model performs on real data given the greater consistency between the theoretical underpinnings of the model and real yield data. This motivates our study.

Our main research questions are as follows: First, how well does the LS2 model fit real yield data? Second, are the results of these tests similar across different fixed-income markets? Finally, how well does the LS2 model work in terms of forecasting yields? The primary contribution of our paper is that we conduct our empirical tests of the term structure models using real yield data. We perform carefully constructed and appropriate tests of the LS2 model using a range of international real yield data. Specifically, the countries we examine are Australia; Canada; France; Germany; Italy; Japan; the UK and the US. Further, we compare and contrast the LS2 model with the one-factor CIR counterpart. Finally, we evaluate the forecasting performance of both models.

Our paper is organised as follows. Section 2 briefly reviews related empirical work on term structure modelling, with particular attention given to a multifactor CIR model. Section 3 describes the data and sampling issues. Section 4 outlines the research design adopted. Section 5 presents our empirical results and Section 6 concludes.

sec.title: 2. Literature review
sec.p: Since the seminal paper by Cox, Ingersoll and Ross (1985), the CIR model has been empirically tested and extended by many researchers due to its strong theoretical appeal. Examples include Stambaugh (1988); Brown and Dybvig (1986); Longstaff and Schwartz (1992); Gibbons and Ramaswamy (1993); Pearson and Sun (1994); Balduzzi et al. (1998); Bansal and Zhou (2002); and Chen and Scott (2003).1 Stambaugh (1988) employs nominal Treasury-bill data to test the prediction of the CIR model that conditional expected holding period returns of discount bonds are linearly related to forward rates.2 He rejects a one-factor model but finds only weak evidence for more than two factors. The main issues with the Stambaugh approach are that the data used are based on nominal yields and that neither the underlying state variables are uncovered, nor the parameters of the CIR model are estimated. Brown and Dybvig (1986) also base their cross-sectional analysis on nominal Treasury-bill data. Failing to make use of the theoretical distribution of an instantaneous riskless rate implied by the model, they also cannot identify the speed of adjustment to the mean and market prices of risk separately and, hence, they fail to estimate all four parameters of the CIR model.

Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) develop a two-factor general equilibrium model of the term structure of real interest rates using the CIR framework. Specifically, they use the short-term interest rate and the instantaneous variance of changes in the short-term interest rate as the two factors underlying the dynamics of the term structure. The advantage of this model is that its dynamics and factor risk premium are all endogenously determined and consistently estimated using the generalized method of moments (GMM). Their empirical analysis is conducted with nominal (Treasury) yield data and their approach depends on the assumption that the estimates for the two factors do not contain measurement error.

Other two-factor CIR models are proposed, inter alia, by Pearson and Sun (1994) and Balduzzi et al. (1998). Pearson and Sun’s (1994) factors are real rates and the price level; and again they estimate the model using nominal yield data. Pearson and Sun do not include price level data in estimating and testing the model, due to a concern about the averaging problem of consumer price index (CPI) data. Moreover, to obtain tractable likelihood functions Pearson and Sun assume no measurement error by restricting the number of cross-sections for the bond rates to be equal to the number of factors.3 They employ the conditional density of state variables to estimate the one- and two-factor model and reject both. In contrast, Balduzzi et al. (1998) use nominal yield data to estimate a two-factor CIR model, where the level of the short-rate and a linear combination of any two rates, termed ‘central tendency’, are the two factors. While this model complements the LS2 model, their objective is to use the two-factor model to understand the dynamics of the short rate.

Gibbons and Ramaswamy (1993) are the first to realize the importance of testing the term structure of real rates with matching real yield data. They use GMM to estimate and conduct an empirical test of the one-factor real CIR model using real yield data, constructed from the US Treasury bills and the Consumer Price Index. They begin with the assumption that the price level is independent of the real economy and employ the steady-state distribution of the real interest rate to calculate the unconditional means, variances and covariances of real yields to maturity of nominal discount bonds. The major disadvantage of Gibbons and Ramaswamy (1993) is that they can use only Treasury bills, the drawback being that such prices are less sensitive to the model parameters relative to (omitted) long-term coupon bonds. In addition, their approach can be applied only to discount bonds and there are not enough coupon bonds available to construct the implied prices of discount bonds with various times to maturity without interpolation or extrapolation.

Bansal and Zhou (2002) develop a term structure model in which the short-interest rate and the market price of risk are subject to discrete regime shifts. Using Efficient Method of Moments (EMM) and the same dataset as LS2, they reject standard affine models that do not include a regime shift with up to three factors and find that the two-factor regime-switching model with a regime-dependent risk premium best fits the data. Chen and Scott (2003) estimate a multifactor CIR model using nominal yield data and a Kalman filter estimation technique. They find support for a three-factor model, which is an extension of the LS2 model.

Iryna et al. (2011) estimate structurally a model of the two-factor term structure of interest rates that is determined through the interaction of risk-averse arbitrageurs and preferred-habitat investors with preferences for specific maturities, based on the US real rates during the 2000s. The two factors are the short-rate and the preferred-habitat demand. They find that the puzzling drop in long rates during 2004–05 (Greenspan conundrum) is driven by the demand factor.

Until recently, most of previous literature on the term structure is US based. International evidence now includes Brown and Schaefer (1994), Ang and Bekaert (2002), Treepongkaruna and Gray (2003), Navas (2005), Treepongkaruna (2005), Psaradakis et al. (2006) and Nowman (2010). Brown and Schaefer (1994) assume that that the long-term rate and the spread between the short and long rates are the two factors driving the dynamics of the term structure. They fit the two-factor CIR model using swap rates data from six countries, namely, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the US. Ang and Bekaert (2002) examine a regime-switching model of short-term interest rate for the US, the UK and Germany and find non-linearities are important in modelling the term structure. Treepongkaruna and Gray (2003) examine the robustness of the one-factor model in the US, the UK, Japan, France, Germany, Italy, Switzerland and Australia using both GMM and quasi-maximum likelihood estimation. They find that parameter estimates are not robust to different countries, data sets, time periods, sampling frequencies and estimation techniques.

Navas (2005) fits the yield curve in the Euro area with the LS2 model, with a no-arbitrage two-factor model and a one-factor CIR model using nominal interest rates. Navas (2005) finds that the one-factor CIR is the preferred model among the three models. Treepongkaruna (2005) evaluates forecasting and finite sample performance of short-rate models in Australia, France, Italy, Japan, Singapore and the US and finds potential danger in over-parmeterization and the general limitation of short-rate models. Finally, Psaradakis et al. (2006) examine regime switching models for the G7 countries and document that the (generalized) expectations hypothesis cannot be rejected when they allow for a risk premium with Markov regimes, provided that instrumental variables are used to account for endogeneity. Nowman (2010) estimates the Generalized Vasicek term structure model using United Kingdom and Euro nominal yield data and concludes that the two-factor model provides a good description of the UK and Euro yield curves.

sec.title: 3.1. Data
sec.p: Our dataset consists of monthly observations of bill and bond nominal yields and the CPI for Australia (AUS), Canada (CAN), France (FRA), Germany (GER), Italy (ITA), Japan (JAP), the United Kingdom (UK) and the United States (US). These eight countries cover more than 70% of the global government bond market.5 All our data (yields and CPI), with the exception of US yields, are collected from Datastream.6 The US yields are obtained from the Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP).

Table 1 presents a summary of the sample periods and maturities covered for each market. For example, for AUS, we collect 3-month, 6-month, 5-year and 10-year nominal (3m, 6m, 5y, 10y) yield data from February 1976 to December 2006, resulting in 371 observations for the full sample. To assess the forecasting performance of each model, we also partition our sample into two sub-samples, creating an in-sample and an out-of-sample analysis for each country. These partitions are also summarized in Table 1. For example, for AUS, the in-sample period is February 1976 to December 2002 (323 observations), while the out-of-sample period is January 2003 to December 2006 (48 observations). Finally, for all countries, with the exception of Australia, we collect monthly data on the CPI – in the case of Australia only quarterly CPI exists.7

caption.p: Summary of sample periods for each market.

This table reports a summary of the maturities sampled from the eight debt markets: Australia (AUS); Canada (CAN); France (FRA); Germany (GER); Italy (ITA); Japan (JAP); the UK (UK); and the US (US). Maturities range from 1 month (1m) to 20 years (20y). The dates and number of observations for the full sample, as well as the in-sample and out-of-sample partitions, are also displayed. Note that for the US data, missing data from the Center for Research in Security Prices for the out-of-sample periods are replaced by data from the H.15 database of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

sec.title: 3.2. Summary statistics8
sec.p: The shapes of the yield curve and volatilities (standard deviations) are similar across all sample periods for almost all countries. That is, on average, the yield curve is typically upward sloping, except for the UK, which exhibits a ‘hump’ shape for the in-sample and full-sample periods. The yield volatilities, on average, decrease with the maturities for all sample periods for almost all countries, except for GER and JAP. For the GER yields, the yield volatilities increase with maturity for the full and in-sample periods but decrease with maturity for the out-of-sample period. For the JAP yields, yield volatilities increase with maturity for all sample periods. Finally, for all sample periods, nominal yields for all countries exhibit a high degree of persistence with the full-sample period being the most persistent and the out-of-sample period being the least persistent.

Figure 1 plots historical nominal yield curves for all countries examined for the full sample period. Over time, yield curves are quite different across the sample countries. In general, the yield curve is downward (upward) sloping when the level of interest rate is relatively high (low) and flat most of the time. For example, relatively high interest rate levels and downward sloping yield curves can be found around the mid 1980s to early 1990s for AUS yields (when the Australian authorities implemented a high-interest regime as ‘necessary’ medicine to curb Australia’s appetite for imports and debt); around the late 1980s and early 1990s for CAN yields (when the Canadian authorities raised interest rates to fight high levels of inflation); around the early 1990s for the FRA, ITA and UK yields (when the European currency crisis erupts); around the late 1970s and early 1980s for US yields (when the US authorities implemented the Fed experiment).

caption.p: Historical nominal yield curve. This figure plots actual historical yields curve for the following eight countries: Australia (AUS), Canada (CAN), France (FRA), Germany (GER), Italy (ITA), Japan (JAP), United Kingdom (UK), and United States (US).

sec.title: 4.1. Basic method
sec.p: This study is built upon the LS2 model.9 The short-term interest rate r and the variance of changes in the short-term interest rate V, which are easily estimated or obtained, are chosen as two underlying factors driving the term structure of real yields. That is, the equilibrium value of F(r, V, τ), a riskless unit discount bond with τ periods until maturity derived by Longstaff and Schwartz (1992), is
where
and

Equation (1) implies that the equilibrium value of a riskless unit discount bond with τ periods until maturity is a function of variables r, V and τ, and depends on six underlying parameters: α, β, γ, δ, η and ν. Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) further express the yield on a τ-maturity bond, Yτ, and change in yield on a τ-maturity bond, ΔYτ, as follows:
The specification in equation (3) and the assumption that volatility follows a GARCH(1, 1) process:10
allow Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) to estimate their two-factor model.

Following Longstaff and Schwartz (1992), we first estimate the conditional volatility of the short-term real yield using GARCH(1, 1) with variance in the mean equation.11 Plots for actual change in real short rate versus the absolute change in yield implied by the GARCH(1, 1) model demonstrate that the model performs extremely well for AUS and US yields, relatively well for FRA and ITA, and poorly for CAN, GER, JAP and UK.12

It should be noted that the major difference between Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) and our paper is the input to the GMM estimation13. Instead of using nominal yield as an input to GMM, we adjust the nominal yield by the CPI14. Effectively, we test the model of the real yield with real yield data. Hence, changes in observed values of the real yield, the short-term real yield and its conditional volatility serve as input into Hansen’s (1982) GMM estimation with the following moment conditions:

Where

is the change in observed yield on a τ-maturity bond. The number of moment conditions depends on the number of maturities of the observed yield. Thus, if we have observed yields on n different maturities and m2 different parameters, we will have 3n moment conditions, resulting in 3n − m2 over-identifying restrictions on a system of moment equations using the GMM approach.

In addition, for comparative purposes we also estimate the one-factor model and obtain GMM difference statistics to test which model performs better. To obtain the specification of the one-factor CIR model, we follow Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) by imposing the restrictions α = δ = γ = 0 and express the yield on a τ-maturity bond, Yτ, and the change in the yield on a τ-maturity bond, ΔYτ , as follows:
where
For the one-factor model, the changes in observed values of real yield as well as the short-term real yield are the inputs to Hansen’s (1982) GMM estimation with the following moment conditions:

Thus, if we have observed yields on n different maturities and m1 parameters, we will have 2n moment conditions, resulting in 2n − m1 over-identifying restrictions on a system of moment equations using the GMM approach.

sec.title: 4.2. Forecasting
sec.p: To assess the performance of both the one-factor CIR and two-factor Longstaff and Schwartz models, we perform a forecasting exercise as follows. First, for both models, we estimate GMM parameters during the in-sample period. Given the GMM estimates, we then back out two unknown parameters λ and η for the two-factor model and one unknown risk-premium parameter for the one-factor model during the in-sample periods.15

Next, we fit various ARIMA(p, d, q)(P, Q, D)s-GARCH(m, n) specifications to the CPI, the two unknown parameters λ and η for the two-factor model and the one unknown risk-premium parameter for the one-factor model during the in-sample period in order to identify the best time-series specifications for these parameters.16 We then adopt the identified time series specifications to the rolling sample window to obtain out-of-sample forecasts for these series.

The general specification of ARIMA(p, d, q) (P, Q, D)s -GARCH(m, n) that we adopt for the CPI, the two unknown parameters λ and η for the two-factor model and the one unknown risk-premium parameter for the one-factor model during the in-sample period can be written as follows:

where L is the lag operator, p, q, P, Q are integers taking values greater than or equal to zero, s, d, D are integers taking values greater than zero (if they are equal to zero, the model becomes a basic ARMA specification),φi are parameters of the autoregressive part of the model, θi are parameters of the moving average part, fi are parameters of autoregressive part of seasonal part of the model, Θi are parameters of the moving average part of seasonal part of the model, αi are parameters of moving average part in the variance equation, βi are parameters of autoregressive part of the variance equation, Zt ~ iid N(0,1), where p, q are nonseasonal Autoregressive Moving Average Model (ARMA) coefficients, d is the number of nonseasonal differences, P is the number of multiplicative autoregressive coefficients, Q is the number of multiplicative moving average coefficients, s is seasonal period, m is the number of autoregressive terms in the variance equation, n is the number of moving average terms in the variance equation and Xt is the variable of interest that we want to model (i.e., the two unknown parameters λ and η for the two-factor model and one unknown risk-premium parameter for the one-factor model). For each time series of interest, we fit a variety of versions of equation (9) using different combinations of d, p, q, P, Q, D, m and n, ranging from 0 to 2. We then identify the best model using the Schwarz Bayesian information criterion and the Akiake information criterion, and the Lagrange multiplier (LM) test. Table 2 reports the final model that we adopt for each variable of interest.

caption.p: Summary of time-series models adopted for consumer price index (CPI), h, g and l

This table reports a summary of the best-fit time-series models over the in-sample period for CPI, the consumer price index; h, g, which are the two unknown parameters from the Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) (LS2) model; and l, the single unknown parameter from the one-factor Cox, Ingersoll and Ross (CIR) model. The time-series model is ARIMA(p, d, q)(P, D, Q)s-GARCH(m, n) where p, q are nonseasonal ARMA coefficients, d is the number of nonseasonal differences, P is the number of multiplicative autoregressive coefficients, Q is the number of multiplicative moving average coefficients, s is the seasonal period, m is the number of autoregressive terms in the variance equation, n is the number of moving average terms in the variance equation and BIC stands for the Schwarz Bayesian information criterion.

sec.p: Given the GMM estimates and the time-series estimates for the remaining unknown parameters, we can obtain the real yield for each term structure model. We then convert the real yield to nominal yield using the forecasted CPI series and finally compute the following forecast errors for both in- and out-of-sample periods:

where ME is the mean error; MAE is the mean absolute error; RMSE is the root mean square error; U is Theil (1958, 1966)’s inequality; yi, yi are forecasted and actual yields, respectively; and N is the number of observations. For ME, MAE and RMSE, a smaller value indicates a better forecast. Theil’s inequality ranges from 0 to 1, and the closer its value is to zero, the better is the forecast. In addition, we also conduct a battery of unbiasedness tests for the in-sample forecast by regressing the forecast yield on the actual yield as follows:

where
y ^
t
is the forecast yield, yt is the observed yield and ϵ ~ N (0,1). We test the null hypothesis whether α = 0,β = 1. Finally, we bias adjust the out-of-sample forecasts using the in-sample mean.

sec.title: 5.1. GMM estimates
sec.p: Table 3 reports GMM estimates for both the one-factor CIR and LS2 models for all countries examined. Like Longstaff and Schwartz (1992), we find that the cross-sectional restrictions imposed by the two-factor model cannot be rejected at conventional significance levels for almost all countries examined, except for JAP, whereas the cross-sectional restrictions imposed by the one-factor model can be rejected for almost all countries examined, except for CAN and GER. Results from the two-factor model are very encouraging since the cross-sectional restrictions are imposed on yields with maturities up to 5 years (for US yields), 10 years (for AUS and ITA yields) and 20 years (for CAN and GER yields). This implies that the two-factor model holds for the entire yield curve (i.e. short-term, immediate and long-term maturities). This result is particularly impressive since Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) note that previous empirical studies often find the explanatory power of equilibrium term structure models drops rapidly for maturities in excess of one year and they find that their 1992 model holds for only short-term and intermediate maturities.

caption.p: Generalized method of moments (GMM) tests of the cross-sectional restrictions on monthly changes in real yield implied by the one-factor Cox, Ingersoll and Ross (CIR) and two-factor Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) (LS2) models.

This table reports the GMM tests of the cross-sectional restrictions on the change in real yield implied by the one-factor CIR and two-factor Longstaff and Schwartz models for the following countries: Australia (AUS), Canada (CAN), France (FRA), Germany (GER), Italy (ITA), Japan (JAP), United Kingdom (UK) and the United States (US). For the two-factor (one-factor) model, the four (two) parameters are estimated from a system of 9 moment conditions for AUS, 27 for CAN, 18 for FRA and GER, 21 for JAP and ITA, 24 for the UK and for the US.. The data are monthly and are expressed in annualised form. The estimation sample period is March 1976 to December 2002 for AUS (323 observations), January 1990 to December 2002 for CAN (156 observations), July 1992 to December 2002 for FRA (126 observations), December 1993 to December 2002 for GER (109 observations), April 1991 to December 2002 for ITA (141 observations), March 1993 to December 2002 for JAP (118 observations), February 1988 to December 2002 for the UK (179 observations) and June 1964 to December 1989 for the US (307 observations).

sec.p: Like Longstaff and Schwartz (1992), we find that the fit between the actual and the two-factor model standard deviations is very close across all sample periods and all countries examined. For example, unreported summary statistics indicates that the actual standard deviations range from 0.0274 in the 3-month US yield to 0.0252 in the 5-year US yield for the in-sample period. The standard deviation implied by the two-factor model (unreported) ranges from 0.0268 in the 3-month US yield to 0.0253 in the 5-year US yield. The mean difference between the actual and two-factor model standard deviations is only 0.0007 for the AUS yields; 0.003 for the CAN yields; 0.02 for the FRA yields; 0.004 for the GER yields; 0.002 for ITA yields; 0.0008 for JAP yields; 0.001 for the UK yields; and 0.0003 for the US yields for the full sample period.17 Finally, the GMM difference statistics reported in Table 3 are significant at the 10% level for almost all countries examined, except for France and Japan. This indicates that the restrictions imposed by the one-factor CIR model are rejected in all but these two cases. Hence, the results of the GMM difference statistics in Table 3 broadly confirm superiority of the two-factor model over the one-factor model.

As we fit a stationary model to a dataset that spans almost 30 years for the US and there have been significant regime shifts in the way that the Federal Reserve has handled the money supply and interest rates, we run a battery of robustness checks over different sample periods for the US data.18 Table 4 reports GMM estimates for both the one-factor CIR and LS2 models for the US during different sample subperiods that accord with widely acknowledged regimes within the market. These results strongly confirm our findings in Table 3 that the LS2 model is superior to the CIR model.

caption.p: Generalized method of moments (GMM) tests of the cross-sectional restrictions on monthly changes in US real yield implied by the one-factor Cox, Ingersoll and Ross (CIR) and two-factor Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) (LS2) models for different sub-sample periods.

td.italic: Panel A: June 1964 to Dec 1989 (307 observations)
Panel B: June 1964 to Dec 2002 (463 observations)
Panel C: June 1964 to Dec 1979 (187 observations)
Panel D: Jan 1982 to Dec 1992 (132 observations)
Panel E: Jan 1993 to Dec 2006 (168 observations)

sec.p: In addition, we examine the ability of the one- and two-factor models to fit actual yields at different points in time along the yield curve. Figure 2 compares the historical yields to the maturity of actual nominal yields with those implied by GMM estimates of the one-factor CIR and LS2 models.19 Panel A presents the yields in December 2001 (for AUS), April 1999 (for FRA), May 1999 (for GER) and January 1972 (for the US), illustrative of when interest rates were low in each country. Similarly, Panel B presents the yields in April 1982 (for AUS), August 1992 (for FRA), September 1994 (for GER) and August 1981 (for the US), illustrative of when interest rates were high. Panel C presents the yields in October 1977 (for AUS), May 2001 (for FRA), May 1996 (for GER) and August 1987 (for the US), illustrative of when interest rates were moderate.20 Finally, Panel D presents the average yields over the in-sample period.

caption.p: Actual nominal yields versus those implied by GMM estimates. This figure compares actual historical yields to maturity with those implied by GMM estimates of the one-factor CIR and two-factor LS models for a sample of countries examined. Panel A presents the yields when interest rates were low. Panel B presents the yields when interest rates were high. Panel C presents the yields when interest rates were moderate. Panel D presents the average yields over the in-sample period.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 2, for all countries, except for the AUS yields (during average yield period) and the FRA and GER yields (during the high interest rate period), the yields implied by the LS2 model track the actual yield curve better than those by the one-factor model for all shapes of yield curves (i.e. regardless of whether rates are high, moderate or low).

sec.title: 5.2. Forecasting results
sec.p: Table 5 reports RMSE for both in- and out-of-sample periods for all countries examined. Panel A of the table, which reports the in-sample forecast performance, indicates the superiority of the LS2 model over the CIR one-factor model across all term-to-maturities and countries examined. Based on a battery of unbiasedness tests for our in-sample forecasts as described in equation (11) (unreported), we found that our in-sample forecasts are biased with the t-statistics on coefficients α and β showing statistical significance at conventional levels in almost all cases. Accordingly, we bias-adjust our out-of-sample forecasts using the in-sample mean and these results are tabulated in Panel B of Table 5.

caption.p: Root mean square error (RMSE) metric from the one-factor Cox, Ingersoll and Ross (CIR) and two-factor Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) (LS2) models.

In Panel A (B), this table reports root mean square error, RMSE, during the in-sample (out-of-sample) period for the Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) two-factor model and the Cox, Ingersoll and Ross (1985) one-factor model for the following eight countries: Australia (AUS), Canada (CAN), France (FRA), Germany (GER), Italy (ITA), Japan (JAP), United Kingdom (UK) and the United States (US). For all countries, the in-sample period ends on December 2002, except for the US which ends on December 1989. The in-sample period starts on March 1976 for AUS (323 observations), January 1990 for CAN (156 observations), July 1992 for FRA (126 observations), December 1993 for GER (109 observations), April 1991 for ITA (141 observations), March 1993 for JAP (118 observations), February 1988 for the UK (179 observations) and June 1964 for the US (307 observations). For all countries except the US, the out-of-sample period is January 2003 to December 2006, resulting in 48 observations. For the US, the out-of-sample period is January 1990 to Dec 2006 (205 observations). The out-of-sample forecasts are bias-adjusted using the mean from the in-sample period.

sec.p: Panel B of this table indicates the superiority of the two-factor model in overall out-of-sample forecast performance across all term-to-maturities for four countries: Australia, Japan, the UK and the US. Further, the two-factor model performs better in forecasting than does the one-factor model only for the short end of CAN yields (2 and 3 months). The relatively poor out-of-sample forecast performance of the two-factor model in some part of the CAN yield curves and the entire FRA, GER and ITA yield curves, could be due to the relatively large difference in short-rate volatilities during the in-sample and out-of-sample periods for these four countries.21 For example, the volatilities of the short CAN yield during the in- and out-of-sample periods are 0.0272 and 0.007, respectively, whereas the volatilities of the short US yield during the in- and out-of-sample periods are only 0.0267 and 0.0123, respectively.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: This paper adopts Hansen’s generalized method of moments (GMM) framework to test the cross-sectional restrictions imposed by the Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) two-factor model as well as the Cox–Ingersoll–Ross one-factor model using real yields in eight different markets: Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US. Our contributions to the existing literature are three fold. First, we appropriately test the term structure models, developed for the real economy using real yields. Second, we propose an efficient method of forecasting the yield curve that utilises all available information up to the date of forecast and allowing us to achieve minimal forecast errors. Third, we examine an extensive international dataset across eight different markets, which collectively account for over 70% of world government bond markets. Specifically, covering eight different markets over the past few decades allows us to fit and test term structures models to different shapes of the yield curve. It also allows us to examine different market structures. We find that we can reject the one-factor model in favour of the Longstaff and Schwartz two-factor model using the GMM difference statistics for six out of eight countries examined. Hence, we support Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) that the two-factor model is a better fit for the following six countries: Australia, Canada, Germany, Italy, the UK and the US. In addition, we also measure the forecasting ability from both the one- and two-factor models. We find that the in-sample forecasts are superior to the out-of-sample forecasts in all cases. For all countries, we find that in-sample forecasts from the LS2 model are superior to those from the one-factor CIR model. Moreover, for Australia, Japan, the UK and the US, we find out-of-sample forecasts from the LS2 model are superior to those from the one-factor CIR model. That is, our findings generally support the two-factor model and, hence, indicate that both the short-term interest rate and the volatility of changes in the short-term interest rates are important factors in modelling the term structure of interest rates. Thus, our study confirms general reliability of prior research in this area, despite the use of nominal data in the modelling of earlier tests.

ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the helpful comments of Tom Smith, Kenneth Roskelley, Ramzi Ben Abdallah and participants at the FMA European Conference 2007, Barcelona and EFMA Conference 2007, Vienna.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
Date of acceptance of final transcript: 7 March 2012.
Accepted by Associate Editor, Tom Smith (Finance).
Longstaff and Schwartz (1992), Gibbons and Ramaswamy (1993) and Chen and Scott (2003) are most closely related to our paper.
Unless otherwise stated, all studies discussed in this section make use of nominal data.
Measurement error arises when there are more bond rates than unobservable factors or state variables.
To conserve space, we suppress discussion of the differing institutional background pertaining to each market.

According to the Datastream government bond indices manual, as of 2000, 31.4% of world government bond market is JAP, 27% is US, 5.5% is UK, 1.5% is CAN and 0.6% is AUS. In addition, 31.7% of the world government bond market is Euroland, which includes 11 members of the European Union. We include France, Germany and Italy in our analysis, as these countries are the major issuers in the EU bond market. In 2004, the net borrowing of these biggest debt issuers was as high as the volume outstanding of the seven ‘small’ euro area countries together.

For all countries other than Australia and the US, we choose long-term Datastream benchmark government indices as proxies for long-term yields. The benchmarks are based on single bonds, which are chosen at the beginning of each month as the most representative for the given maturity. According to Datastream, benchmark bonds are selected according to the accepted conventions within each market and in general, they are the latest issue within the given maturity band, though yield, liquidity, issue size and coupon are also taken into account. See Datastream manual on government bond indices for more details. For yields with maturity less than one year, we use instruments that are similar to US Treasury bills (discussed later in this section).
For simplicity we linearly interpolate monthly CPI figures between each quarterly observation.
To conserve space, we do not report summary statistics. More details are available from the authors upon request.
See Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) for a detailed derivation and interpretation of the model.

This specification allows us to empirically test the cross-sectional restrictions implied by equation 3 as a set of over-identifying restrictions on a system of moment equations using the GMM approach of Hansen (1982).
For the FRA, GER, ITA short rates, we fit the GARCH(1, 1) model since it fits these data better.
To conserve space, we do not report these plots. They are available from the authors upon request.

Although other estimation methods such as maximum likelihood and efficient method of moments can be used, we intentionally adopt the GMM estimation method so that our results are readily comparable to the Longstaff and Schwartz (1992) original paper.
Our conversion from nominal to real yields is a straightforward application of Fisher equation.
For the forecast exercise, we use Chan et al. (1992) moment conditions to obtain GMM estimates for three unknown parameters in the one-factor CIR model.
The best model is selected as that which achieves the minimum value of the Schwarz Bayesian criterion and the Akiake criterion. Detailed results are available upon request.
As noted by Longstaff and Schwartz (1992), the moment restrictions adopted do not impose the restriction that these moments (mean, standard deviation, or higher moments) match.

Specifically, we also ran in- and out-of-sample forecasts for all sample periods reported in Table 4 and generally confirmed the superiority of the 2-factor model. Further, we extended the in-sample period for the US data from June 1964 to December 2002 (to be consistent with other countries) and found similar results as reported here. In addition, we also ran other robustness checks for the US data by using data sourced from H.15 database of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which allow more term-to-maturities to be included in estimation. Overall, these results are consistent with results reported in this paper. These results are not reported to conserve space but are available from the authors upon request.
To conserve space, we show only half of the countries examined. Results for countries not reported reveal that the LS2 model is superior to the one-factor CIR model in all cases.

We do not pretend that the cases shown in Panels A, B and C are definitive in any way. Rather the purpose is to give a general feel for the three characterised regimes: ‘low’, ‘moderate’ and ‘high’ interest rates, as appropriate for each market. Our choices are arbitrary.
However, this also might be due to significant time variation in the entire return distribution, not just the second moment.
